name: Dogo Onsen
short_description: Japan's oldest hot spring with a historic bathhouse that inspired Studio Ghibli's Spirited Away.
description:
Dogo Onsen boasts a proud history of approximately 3,000 years, making it one of Japan's oldest and most famous hot springs. The iconic Dogo Onsen Honkan, a three-story wooden bathhouse built in 1894, was the first public bathhouse in Japan to be designated as a National Important Cultural Property. Its labyrinthine interior of stairways, passages, and rooms has served as inspiration for the bathhouse in Hayao Miyazaki's beloved animated film 'Spirited Away.'

The bathhouse offers multiple bathing experiences at different price levels, from the basic Kami no Yu bath to the more exclusive Tama no Yu with private relaxation rooms. Visitors can also tour the Yushinden, a special bathroom reserved for the Imperial Family. The surrounding area features a charming shopping arcade, traditional ryokan inns, and the nearby Ishiteji Temple, making it a complete cultural destination.

The area has been a frequent destination for Japan's most prestigious guests, including the Imperial Family. After bathing, visitors traditionally stroll through the Dogo Haikara Dori shopping arcade in yukata robes, enjoying local specialties like 'Botchan dango' sweet dumplings and mikan citrus products.

name: Matsuyama Castle
short_description: One of Japan's 12 original castles with an intact keep, offering panoramic city views from Mount Katsuyama.
description:
Matsuyama Castle is one of Japan's twelve 'original castles' that have survived the post-feudal era since 1868 with their keeps intact. Perched atop Mount Katsuyama at 132 meters elevation in the heart of Matsuyama city, the castle provides spectacular 360-degree panoramic views of the city, the Seto Inland Sea, and the surrounding mountains. Construction began in 1602 under Kato Yoshiaki and took over 20 years to complete, making it one of the longest castle construction projects in Japanese history.

The castle complex is remarkably well-preserved, with 21 buildings designated as Important Cultural Properties. The main keep, rebuilt in 1854 after being destroyed by lightning, features multiple wings and defensive structures including the only surviving watchtower-style double turret in Japan. Inside, visitors can explore exhibits about Matsuyama's feudal history, view samurai armor and weapons, and experience the castle's ingenious defensive architecture.

Access to the hilltop castle is convenient via ropeway or chairlift, with the single-chair lift being a particularly pleasant and popular experience. Shiroyama Park at the base features approximately 200 cherry trees, making this one of Japan's Top 100 Cherry Blossom Spots, especially beautiful from late March to early April.

name: Ritsurin Garden
short_description: One of Japan's finest historical gardens with six ponds, 13 hills, and over 1,000 meticulously pruned pine trees.
description:
Ritsurin Garden is a stunning stroll garden of the daimyo style and the largest among Japan's Cultural Property Gardens designated as Special Places of Scenic Beauty. Covering an impressive 750,000 square meters, the garden was completed in 1745 after 100 years of construction by successive feudal lords. It features six ponds and thirteen landscaped hills set against the beautiful backdrop of Mount Shiun, exemplifying the Japanese garden design technique of 'borrowed scenery.'

The garden contains over 1,000 meticulously shaped pine trees, including the famous Neagari Goyomatsu white pine, originally a bonsai tree presented as a gift from the Tokugawa shogun in 1833. The southern portion showcases traditional Japanese design with historic teahouses, while the northern section underwent Western-style redesigns after opening to the public in 1875. The Kikugetsutei teahouse offers visitors the opportunity to enjoy matcha tea while overlooking the serene ponds.

Ritsurin has received three stars in the Michelin Green Guide Japan, putting it on par with Japan's celebrated 'three great gardens.' The garden is particularly stunning during seasonal light-up events for cherry blossoms in spring and autumn foliage. Traditional boat rides on the ponds offer a unique perspective once reserved for feudal lords.

name: Kotohira-gu Shrine
short_description: Historic shrine dedicated to sailors featuring 1,368 stone steps climbing Mount Zozu with panoramic views.
description:
Kotohira-gu, affectionately known as Konpira-san, is the head shrine of approximately 600 Kotohira shrines throughout Japan dedicated to sailors and seafaring. Located on the wooded slopes of Mount Zozu, the shrine is famous for its challenging approach consisting of 785 stone steps to the main shrine and an additional 583 steps to the inner shrine, totaling 1,368 steps. The climb typically takes 45 minutes to the main hall and offers a rewarding journey past shops, cafes, and scenic viewpoints.

The shrine has been worshipped since the Heian period and receives around four million visitors annually. During the Edo period when sea travel was dangerous, hundreds of thousands of pilgrims would make the journey to pray for safe voyages. The shrine grounds display Buddhist and Shinto architectural elements, reflecting its pre-Meiji history as a combined religious site. Notable features include the Ema Hall displaying pictures of ships, battleships, and even space rockets whose crews sought the shrine's protection.

The approach is lined with souvenir shops selling traditional items like walking sticks, yellow 'happiness' amulets (Kofuku no Kiiroi Omamori), and fan-shaped 'kamiyo ame' candies. The area is also famous for Sanuki udon noodles. From the main hall and inner shrine, visitors are rewarded with sweeping panoramic views over the Sanuki Plain and Seto Inland Sea.

name: Naoshima Island
short_description: Art island in the Seto Inland Sea featuring world-class contemporary museums and Yayoi Kusama's iconic pumpkin sculptures.
description:
Naoshima is a small island of approximately 8 square kilometers in the Seto Inland Sea that has transformed into an international center for contemporary art. Once a smelter town, it now houses world-renowned museums designed by architect Tadao Ando, including the Benesse House Museum, Chichu Art Museum, and Lee Ufan Museum. The island features permanent installations by artists such as Yayoi Kusama, whose iconic yellow pumpkin sculpture has become a symbol of the island.

The Chichu Art Museum, built mostly underground to preserve the island's natural scenery, displays works by Claude Monet, James Turrell, and Walter De Maria using only natural light, creating an experience that changes throughout the day and seasons. The Art House Project transforms traditional houses in the Honmura village area into art installations, blending contemporary art with the island's historical architecture. The Naoshima Bath 'I♥湯' serves as both a working public bathhouse and an art installation.

The island is accessible by ferry from Takamatsu Port (about 50 minutes) or Uno Port in Okayama. Electric-assist bicycles can be rented at Miyanoura Port to explore the island's art sites, charming fishing villages, and beautiful coastline. The Setouchi Triennale, held every three years, brings additional temporary exhibitions to Naoshima and neighboring islands.

name: Iya Valley Kazurabashi
short_description: Historic vine bridge stretching 45 meters across the Iya River, woven from mountain vines and rebuilt every three years.
description:
Iya Kazurabashi is one of Japan's three rarest bridges and a designated Important Tangible Folk Cultural Property. This dramatic suspension bridge stretches 45 meters long, 2 meters wide, and hangs 14 meters above the crystal-clear Iya River. Woven from approximately 5-6 tons of hardy shirokuchi kazura mountain vines, the bridge is completely rebuilt every three years and reinforced with hidden steel cables for safety. Crossing the swaying bridge with gaps between the slats offers a thrilling experience with views of the rushing water below.

The bridge's origins are surrounded by legend. Some say it was built by members of the defeated Heike (Taira) clan who fled to this remote valley after losing the Gempei War in 1185, creating bridges that could be easily cut if enemies approached. Others attribute it to the Buddhist monk Kobo Daishi who built it to help local villagers. At one time, 13 such bridges spanned the valley, but only three remain today.

The Iya Valley itself is characterized by steep mountain slopes, deep rocky gorges, and isolated hillside hamlets that preserve traditional Japanese rural life. Nearby attractions include the Biwa-no-taki waterfall, hot spring hotels, and the more remote Oku-Iya Double Vine Bridges deeper in the valley. The area is also famous for local specialties like Iya soba noodles and 'deko mawashi' skewers.

name: Naruto Whirlpools
short_description: Spectacular natural phenomenon where tidal currents create massive whirlpools up to 20 meters in diameter.
description:
The Naruto Whirlpools are one of the world's most impressive tidal phenomena, occurring in the Naruto Strait between Naruto in Tokushima Prefecture and Awaji Island. When the waters of the Seto Inland Sea collide with the opposing Pacific Ocean currents in the 1.3-kilometer-wide strait during high and low tide, they create powerful whirlpools reaching up to 20 meters in diameter. The current speed can reach 20 km/h during spring tides, making it one of the world's three greatest tidal currents alongside the Strait of Messina and Seymour Narrows.

The whirlpools occur roughly every six hours and can typically be seen once in the morning and afternoon for one to two hours each. They are largest during spring tides when the sun, earth, and moon align, and tend to be more dramatic in spring and autumn. It's essential to check the whirlpool schedules before visiting, as conditions vary significantly.

Visitors can experience the whirlpools from sightseeing boats that get right up next to them, some featuring underwater viewing windows. Alternatively, the Uzu-no-Michi Walkway, built under the Onaruto Bridge, features glass floor panels suspended 45 meters above the strait, offering a bird's-eye view of the swirling waters. Nearby attractions include the Otsuka Museum of Art and Ryozenji Temple, the first temple of the Shikoku 88 Temple Pilgrimage.

name: Kochi Castle
short_description: The only castle in Japan retaining both its original keep and palace, with 15 surviving structures from the Edo period.
description:
Kochi Castle holds a unique distinction as the only castle in Japan where both the original castle tower (tenshu) and the main keep (honmaru) with the lord's palace remain intact. As one of Japan's twelve original castles with surviving keeps, it offers an authentic glimpse into Edo-period castle architecture. Construction began in 1601 under Yamauchi Kazutoyo after the Battle of Sekigahara, and though much of it burned in 1727, it was meticulously reconstructed by 1753 using traditional methods.

The castle complex features 15 Important Cultural Properties, including the watchtower-style keep, the Honmaru Palace (Kaitokukan), and the impressive Otemon main gate. Unlike most castles where lords resided in separate palace buildings, Kochi Castle's keep served both military and residential purposes. The wooden interior maintains its Edo-period appearance with steep staircases, narrow defensive windows, and tatami rooms. From the top floor, visitors enjoy panoramic views of Kochi City and the surrounding Shikoku Mountains.

A unique feature is the ability to capture both the Otemon gate and castle tower in a single photograph, rare among Japanese castles. The castle grounds are popular for cherry blossom viewing in spring, with colorful lanterns creating a dramatic atmosphere after dark. The surrounding park area includes statues of notable local figures, including Itagaki Taisuke, leader of Japan's Freedom and People's Rights Movement.

name: Hirome Market
short_description: Lively indoor food court with 60+ stalls serving Kochi's famous katsuo tataki and local specialties in a communal atmosphere.
description:
Hirome Market is the vibrant culinary heart of Kochi, often called 'Kochi's Kitchen.' This indoor food court-style venue opened in 1998 to celebrate and preserve the region's food culture, housing approximately 60 eateries and retail shops under one roof. Named after Shigeaki Hirome Fukao, a revered chief retainer of the Tosa Domain, the market occupies the site of his former residence. The atmosphere resembles a festival every day, with communal tables encouraging interaction between locals and visitors.

The market's star attraction is katsuo no tataki (seared bonito), Kochi's soul food, which you can watch being dramatically prepared over open flames of burning rice straw. Other local specialties include whale dishes, shamo chicken, fresh sashimi, and Tosa Red Beef. The communal dining style means you order from various stalls and bring everything back to shared tables with over 400 seats, where it's common and encouraged to share space with strangers over drinks.

Kochi residents are famous for enjoying their drinks, and Hirome Market is the perfect place to experience this part of local culture. Day drinking is common, and you'll find pilgrims on the 88-temple trail mingling with surfers and salarymen over glasses of smooth local sake. Beyond food, the market offers souvenir shops selling bonito flakes, yuzu products, and local crafts. Located just steps from Kochi Castle, it's an essential stop for any visitor.

name: Otsuka Museum of Art
short_description: Japan's largest museum featuring over 1,000 life-size ceramic reproductions of Western masterpieces including the Sistine Chapel.
description:
The Otsuka Museum of Art is Japan's largest museum by exhibition space, housing a unique collection of over 1,000 ceramic board reproductions of Western art masterpieces from ancient times to the modern era. Founded in 1998 by the Otsuka Pharmaceutical company, the museum uses advanced ceramic plate technology to recreate famous works in their original size, including entire architectural spaces like the Sistine Chapel ceiling and Scrovegni Chapel frescoes.

What makes this museum exceptional is the ability to view and photograph masterpieces that are normally scattered across museums worldwide, all in one location. The collection spans from ancient Egyptian art through Renaissance masters like da Vinci and Michelangelo to Impressionists including Monet and van Gogh. Unlike visiting the original works, visitors can get remarkably close to examine brush strokes and details. The ceramic reproductions are designed to last over 2,000 years without fading.

The museum's walking route covers approximately 4 kilometers, requiring 2-4 hours for a thorough visit. The building is cleverly designed to appear small from outside while offering expansive galleries within. Located in Naruto Park near the whirlpools and Ryozenji Temple, it makes an excellent combined visit. The museum is particularly popular with art educators and students who can experience a comprehensive Western art history education in a single visit.

name: Chichu Art Museum
short_description: Underground museum designed by Tadao Ando displaying Monet, Turrell, and De Maria works illuminated only by natural light.
description:
Chichu Art Museum, opened in 2004, is a subterranean architectural masterpiece designed by Pritzker Prize-winning architect Tadao Ando. Built almost entirely underground to preserve Naoshima's natural scenery, the museum uses only natural light to illuminate its collection, creating an experience that transforms with the passage of time and seasons. The building itself is considered a massive site-specific artwork, with its geometric concrete forms creating dramatic plays of light and shadow.

The museum houses a carefully curated permanent collection of just three artists whose works respond to the unique architectural spaces. Claude Monet's large 'Water Lilies' murals are displayed in a bright, contemplative white room. James Turrell contributes three light installations including 'Open Sky,' an aperture in the ceiling that frames the changing colors of the sky. Walter De Maria's 'Time/Timeless/No Time' fills a vast chamber with a polished granite sphere and golden stairs.

Prior to visiting, the Chichu Garden features approximately 150 types of plants that appeared in Monet's works or were collected by the artist, deepening visitors' appreciation of his paintings. Advance reservations for a specific time slot are strongly recommended, especially during peak seasons. The museum café terrace offers stunning views over the Seto Inland Sea, perfect for reflection after viewing the exhibits.

name: Mount Ishizuchi
short_description: Western Japan's highest peak at 1,982m, sacred mountain with challenging chain climbs and spectacular alpine views.
description:
Mount Ishizuchi, standing at 1,982 meters, is the tallest mountain on Shikoku and in all of western Japan. It has been revered as a sacred peak for centuries in the Shugendo mountain worship tradition, which blends Buddhist and Shinto practices. The mountain draws both spiritual pilgrims and hiking enthusiasts seeking its challenging trails and breathtaking alpine scenery, including stunning views of the Seto Inland Sea on clear days.

The main climbing route features three famous chain sections where pilgrims use iron chains bolted into the rock face to ascend steep cliffs. While these chains are optional (bypass trails exist), they represent the mountain's spiritual challenge and are considered part of the authentic pilgrimage experience. The Ishizuchi Tozan Ropeway provides access to a station at 1,300 meters elevation, from which the summit can be reached in about 2.5-3 hours, though the full hike from base to summit takes approximately 6 hours round trip.

Climbing season runs from early July through mid-November, with October and November offering spectacular autumn colors. The mountain hosts a dramatic opening ceremony each July 1st when hundreds of white-clad pilgrims begin their ascent at dawn. Small temples, shrines, and mountain huts dot the trail. The summit shrine, Ishizuchi Jinja, has been an important pilgrimage destination for over 1,300 years.

name: Ryozenji Temple
short_description: First temple of the famous 88 Temple Shikoku Pilgrimage, where henro pilgrims begin their spiritual journey.
description:
Ryozenji Temple is the sacred starting point of the Shikoku 88 Temple Pilgrimage (Shikoku Henro), one of the world's most important circular pilgrimages. Founded in the 8th century and associated with the Buddhist monk Kobo Daishi (Kukai), this temple marks where countless pilgrims begin their 1,200-kilometer spiritual journey around Shikoku, visiting all 88 temples. The pilgrimage route is one of the few circular pilgrimages in the world and typically takes 40-60 days to complete on foot.

The temple grounds are perpetually bustling with activity as white-clothed henro pilgrims gather to purchase their pilgrimage supplies, including the distinctive sedge hat (sugegasa), white vest (hakui), and walking staff (kongozue). The atmosphere is charged with anticipation as pilgrims prepare to embark on their transformative journey. For those completing the circuit, Ryozenji also serves as the ending point, bringing the pilgrimage full circle.

The temple complex features a fine wooden gate at the entrance, a serene pond with a two-story pagoda, and well-maintained temple buildings. Even for visitors not undertaking the full pilgrimage, experiencing the energy of departing and arriving pilgrims offers a moving glimpse into Japan's living spiritual traditions. The temple provides blessing services, stamp books (nokyocho), and information about the pilgrimage route.

name: Oboke-Koboke Gorge
short_description: Dramatic gorge carved by the Yoshino River featuring marble-like cliffs, scenic boat cruises, and white-water rafting.
description:
Oboke and Koboke are two consecutive gorges created by the Yoshino River near the entrance to the Iya Valley, forming some of the most spectacular scenery in Shikoku. The emerald-green waters flow between towering cliffs of crystalline schist rock that have been sculpted over millions of years into formations resembling polished marble. The gorge names translate roughly to 'big danger' (Oboke) and 'small danger' (Koboke), reflecting the treacherous rapids that once challenged travelers.

Sightseeing boat cruises offer a leisurely 30-minute journey through the gorges, allowing visitors to appreciate the towering cliffs, swaying trees, and sparkling waters from river level. The boats operate year-round, with autumn colors and spring greenery providing particularly stunning backdrops. For more adventurous visitors, the Yoshino River is one of Japan's premier destinations for white-water rafting and kayaking, with rapids ranging from gentle to challenging Class III-IV.

The area serves as the gateway to the deeper Iya Valley and features excellent tourist facilities, including the Oboke Gorge Mannaka complex with restaurants serving local specialties like Iya soba noodles and 'Hidar Ramen,' souvenir shops, and observation decks overlooking the river. The gorge is easily accessible by train on the JR Dosan Line, making it a convenient stop between Kochi and Takamatsu.

name: Katsurahama Beach
short_description: Scenic crescent-shaped beach famous for its Sakamoto Ryoma statue and pine-lined shores, though swimming is prohibited.
description:
Katsurahama Beach is one of Kochi's most iconic landmarks, a beautiful crescent-shaped beach at the entrance to Urado Bay. While swimming is prohibited due to dangerous currents, the beach draws visitors for its stunning scenery, cultural significance, and pine tree-lined shores. The beach has been celebrated in Japanese literature and art for centuries and is particularly beautiful during sunset when the sky paints dramatic colors over the Pacific Ocean.

The beach's most famous landmark is the impressive bronze statue of Sakamoto Ryoma, one of Kochi's most beloved historical figures who played a crucial role in ending the feudal system and modernizing Japan in the 1860s. The statue depicts Ryoma gazing out to sea with his arms folded, symbolizing his forward-thinking vision. A smaller replica allows visitors to stand alongside the samurai hero for photos.

Adjacent to the beach, visitors can explore the Sakamoto Ryoma Memorial Museum, which chronicles his life and revolutionary contributions to Japanese history. The Katsurahama Aquarium offers marine life exhibits and popular sea lion shows. Nearby Tosa Fighting Dog Center showcases the local tradition of dog fighting (now performed ceremonially). The area also features shops selling coral and shell crafts, traditional Kochi products, and the chance to experience Tosa's unique 'ouendan' cheerleading dogs.

name: Shimanto River
short_description: Japan's last clear stream featuring 47 distinctive submersible bridges and excellent canoeing and river activities.
description:
The Shimanto River is celebrated as Japan's last clear stream, flowing 196 kilometers through the mountains of southwestern Kochi Prefecture to the Pacific Ocean. Unlike Japan's other major rivers, the Shimanto has no dams along its main course, preserving its pristine waters and traditional riverside lifestyle. The river's clarity and natural beauty have made it a symbol of environmental preservation and a destination for those seeking unspoiled Japanese nature.

The river is famous for its 47 'chinkabashi' or submersible bridges, distinctive low bridges built without railings that are designed to submerge during floods rather than resist the water's force. These bridges create picturesque scenes as cyclists and pedestrians cross the clear waters, and have become iconic symbols of the region. The most famous is Sada Chinkabashi, often featured in photographs and travel media.

The Shimanto offers excellent opportunities for water activities including canoeing, kayaking, and river cruises aboard traditional 'yakatabune' houseboats. Fishing for sweetfish (ayu) using traditional methods is a popular summer activity. The river valley is also known for its fireflies in early summer. Riverside villages maintain traditional industries including seaweed harvesting and river fishing, offering visitors a glimpse into a way of life increasingly rare in modern Japan.

name: Ishiteji Temple
short_description: Temple #51 on the Shikoku Pilgrimage featuring mysterious cave passages and a treasure trove of Buddhist artifacts near Dogo Onsen.
description:
Ishiteji Temple is Matsuyama's most famous temple and the 51st stop on the Shikoku 88 Temple Pilgrimage. Located just a 20-minute walk from Dogo Onsen, it makes an excellent cultural addition to any hot spring visit. The temple's Niomon gate is designated a National Treasure, and numerous other buildings and artifacts have received Important Cultural Property status. The name 'Ishiteji' means 'Temple of the Stone Hand,' referencing a legend involving Kobo Daishi.

What sets Ishiteji apart from other pilgrimage temples is its mysterious cave system. A fascinating tunnel leads to a secondary temple complex, creating an otherworldly experience as visitors pass statues, stone carvings, and Buddhist imagery in the dimly lit passages. The main cave passage opens to a mountainside area filled with colorful statues, memorial stones, and small shrines scattered across the hillside in a somewhat chaotic but atmospheric arrangement.

The spacious temple grounds feature a three-storied pagoda, multiple halls, and an eclectic collection of religious artifacts accumulated over centuries. The approach is lined with small shops and restaurants, and the temple has a unique atmosphere blending traditional Buddhism with folk religious elements. The temple is known for its connections to henro pilgrimage legend, as this is where the famous story of Emon Saburo and the origin of the pilgrimage tradition is said to have occurred.

name: Uzu-no-Michi Walkway
short_description: Glass-floored observation walkway suspended 45 meters above the Naruto Strait, offering thrilling views of the whirlpools below.
description:
The Uzu-no-Michi (Whirlpool Road) is a 450-meter walkway built beneath the Onaruto Bridge that spans the Naruto Strait. Suspended 45 meters above the churning waters, this enclosed promenade leads visitors to an observation area featuring glass floor panels that provide vertigo-inducing views directly down to the famous Naruto Whirlpools. The experience of watching massive whirlpools form and spin beneath your feet is both thrilling and unforgettable.

The walkway takes advantage of the bridge's unique construction, converting the lower deck maintenance passage into a public attraction. Along the way, informational displays explain the science behind the whirlpool phenomenon and the bridge's engineering. The observation room at the end offers panoramic views of the strait, Awaji Island, and the surrounding coastline, in addition to the dramatic glass-floor sections.

For the best experience, visitors should time their visit to coincide with the whirlpool schedule, as the vortexes form during the tidal changes approximately every six hours. The walkway offers a completely different perspective from the boat tours, allowing visitors to see multiple whirlpools simultaneously and appreciate their full scale from above. Combined with nearby attractions like the Otsuka Museum of Art and Naruto Park's observation decks, it makes for a comprehensive exploration of this remarkable natural phenomenon.

name: Zentsuji Temple
short_description: Birthplace of Kobo Daishi (Kukai) and Temple #75, featuring a pitch-dark underground pilgrimage passage and extensive grounds.
description:
Zentsuji Temple holds extraordinary significance as the birthplace of Kobo Daishi (Kukai), the founder of Shingon Buddhism and the spiritual heart of the Shikoku Pilgrimage. As Temple #75 on the 88-temple circuit, it is one of the pilgrimage's most important destinations. The temple's name is even used for the city that has grown around it, reflecting its central role in regional identity. The extensive grounds are divided into the Eastern Precinct (Toin), containing the Main Hall and birthplace sacred sites, and the Western Precinct (Saiin), housing the five-story pagoda.

The temple's most moving experience is the 'Kaidan Meguri' (underground pilgrimage), a pitch-black passage beneath the Main Hall where visitors walk approximately 100 meters in complete darkness while touching the wall and chanting. The passage symbolizes traversing the realm of the Buddha and emerges near the spot where Kobo Daishi was born in 774 CE. This powerful spiritual experience is unique among the 88 temples and draws pilgrims seeking deep connection with the great master.

The temple complex spans 45,000 square meters and includes numerous Important Cultural Properties, including a five-story pagoda reconstructed in 1845. The Treasury Museum houses religious artifacts, paintings, and items associated with Kobo Daishi. Throughout the year, the temple hosts various ceremonies and festivals, particularly on Kobo Daishi's memorial day (March 21), drawing thousands of devotees.

name: Oku-Iya Double Vine Bridges
short_description: Remote pair of vine bridges nicknamed the 'Husband and Wife Bridges' in the secluded upper Iya Valley.
description:
The Oku-Iya Niju Kazurabashi (Double Vine Bridges) are a pair of suspension bridges deep in the remote upper reaches of the Iya Valley, approximately 30 km from the main Iya Kazurabashi. These 'husband and wife' bridges offer a quieter, more authentic experience than their famous counterpart, with far fewer visitors and a more pristine natural setting. The male bridge spans 42 meters while the female bridge measures 22 meters, both made from woven mountain vines and rebuilt every three years.

What makes this location special is the wild-pulling ropeway (Yaen) nearby – a simple wooden platform on ropes that visitors can pull themselves across the river using their own strength. This thrilling experience adds to the adventurous atmosphere of the deep valley. The surrounding area features hiking trails leading to hidden waterfalls, traditional farmhouses, and the famous Scarecrow Village (Nagoro), where lifelike scarecrows populate an otherwise nearly abandoned hamlet.

Access to the Oku-Iya bridges requires a car or joining a tour, as public transportation is extremely limited. The journey along narrow, winding mountain roads is part of the adventure, passing through landscapes that feel unchanged from centuries past. The isolation has helped preserve traditional ways of life, and visitors may encounter thatched-roof farmhouses, terraced fields, and the descendants of Heike warriors who reportedly fled here after their defeat in the 12th century.

name: Makino Botanical Garden
short_description: Beautiful hillside garden showcasing 3,000 plant species, honoring Japan's 'Father of Botany' Dr. Tomitaro Makino.
description:
The Kochi Prefectural Makino Botanical Garden is a beautiful 8-hectare hillside garden located on Mount Godai, honoring Dr. Tomitaro Makino (1862-1957), Japan's 'Father of Botany.' Born in Kochi, Dr. Makino discovered and named over 1,500 plant species during his lifetime and created detailed botanical illustrations that remain references today. The garden houses approximately 3,000 plant species, including many named or discovered by the renowned botanist.

The garden is designed to showcase the rich plant diversity of Kochi Prefecture, which spans from subtropical coastal areas to alpine zones. Themed areas include a conservatory with tropical plants, traditional herb gardens, and naturalistic woodland walks. The main building, designed by architect Makoto Sei Watanabe, houses a museum with exhibits about Dr. Makino's life, his botanical illustrations, and the history of Japanese botany. The architecture seamlessly integrates with the natural landscape.

The garden gained renewed international attention when NHK's 2023 morning drama 'Ranman' told the story of Dr. Makino's life, drawing visitors eager to learn about this remarkable self-taught scientist who began studying plants as a child and continued his research until age 94. The garden is particularly beautiful during spring when various wildflowers bloom, and autumn when the hillside forest displays vibrant foliage. A restaurant and gift shop offer local products including botanical-themed items.

name: Takamatsu Shopping Arcade
short_description: Japan's longest covered shopping arcade stretching 2.7 km, famous for Sanuki udon restaurants and traditional shops.
description:
Takamatsu's interconnected shopping arcades form the longest covered shopping street in Japan, extending approximately 2.7 kilometers through the heart of the city. The main arcade connects Takamatsu Station to Ritsurin Garden, making it both a practical thoroughfare and a shopping destination. Protected from rain and summer heat by its roof, the arcade bustles with activity from morning to evening, offering a perfect blend of traditional shops, modern retailers, and countless dining options.

The arcade is particularly famous for its concentration of Sanuki udon restaurants, as Kagawa Prefecture is the undisputed udon capital of Japan. Visitors can find dozens of udon shops ranging from traditional standing-only establishments to more elaborate restaurants, each with their own style and devoted following. The thick, chewy noodles are typically served in hot or cold preparations with various toppings. Sampling multiple shops is encouraged, as portions are small and prices extremely reasonable.

Beyond udon, the arcade offers everything from traditional crafts, including Kagawa lacquerware and Marugame fans, to fashion boutiques, electronics stores, and souvenir shops. The historic Lion-dori section features charming architecture and traditional stores. The arcade connects to several covered side streets and the Sunport waterfront area, allowing for hours of exploration. Evening brings a lively atmosphere as restaurants and izakayas open for dinner and drinks.
